@Service
@DisallowConcurrentExecution
public class CartJobConfigLoader implements CartCronJob {

    public static final Logger        LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CartJobConfigLoader.class);

    /**
     * Job manager instance which schedules/unschedules job based on the change in job configuration.
     */
    @Autowired
    private CartJobManager            jobManager;

    /** Dao to fetch job configuration from database. */
    @Autowired
    private CartJobConfigDBRepository jobConfigDao;

    @Transactional(readOnly = true)
    public void loadJobConfigs() {
        for (CartJobConfig jobConfig : jobConfigDao.getAllCronJobs().values()) {
            jobManager.updateJobConfig(jobConfig);
        }
    }

    @Transactional(readOnly = true)
    @Override
    public void execute(JobExecutionContext context) throws JobExecutionException {
        LOG.info("Reloading job configs...");
        loadJobConfigs();
    }

    @Override
    public JobKey getJobKey() {
        return CartJobKeyEnum.CRON_LOADER.getJobKey();
    }

}


@Service
public class CartJobManager {
    public static final Logger             LOG                = LoggerFactory.getLogger(CartJobManager.class);

    private final Map<JobKey, CartCronJob> myKeyedJobs        = new HashMap<>();

    private final Set<JobKey>              myDisabledJobs     = new HashSet<>();
    private final Map<JobKey, String>      myJobCronSchedules = new HashMap<>();

    @Autowired
    private Set<CartCronJob>               myRegisteredJobs;

    @Autowired
    private SchedulerFactoryBean           mySchedulerFactory;

    @PostConstruct
    private void initJobManager() {
        LOG.info("Intialising catalog job manager");
        if (myRegisteredJobs == null || myRegisteredJobs.isEmpty()) {
            LOG.info("No job registered with us, nothing to manage here");
            return;
        }

        for (CartCronJob job : myRegisteredJobs) {
            if (myKeyedJobs.put(job.getJobKey(), job) != null) {
                throw new RuntimeException("More than one catalog jobs registered with key: " + job.getJobKey());
            }
        }
    }

    public void unscheduleJob(JobKey jobKey) {
        Scheduler quartzScheduler = mySchedulerFactory.getScheduler();
        TriggerKey triggerKey = new TriggerKey(jobKey.getName());

        try {
            CronTrigger trigger = (CronTrigger) quartzScheduler.getTrigger(triggerKey);
            if (trigger == null) {
                LOG.info("No trigger already scheduled for job: {}", jobKey);
                return;
            }

            if (quartzScheduler.unscheduleJob(triggerKey)) {
                LOG.info("Successfully unscheduled an existing trigger for job: {}", jobKey);
            }
        } catch (SchedulerException e) {
            LOG.warn("Failed to unschedule an existing trigger for job: " + jobKey, e);
        }
    }

    public void scheduleJob(JobKey jobKey, String cronExpr, Map<String, String> jobDataMap) {
        CartCronJob job = myKeyedJobs.get(jobKey);
        if (job == null) {
            LOG.warn("No job registered with key: {}, ignoring scheduling request", jobKey);
            return;
        }

        unscheduleJob(jobKey);

        try {
            LOG.info("Scheduling job: {} with cron schedule: {}", jobKey, cronExpr);
            JobDetail quartzJob = JobBuilder.newJob(job.getClass()).withIdentity(jobKey.getName()).build();
            if (null != jobDataMap) {
                quartzJob.getJobDataMap().putAll(jobDataMap);
            }
            CronTrigger trigger = TriggerBuilder.newTrigger().withIdentity(new TriggerKey(jobKey.getName())).withSchedule(CronScheduleBuilder.cronSchedule(cronExpr)).build();
            mySchedulerFactory.getScheduler().scheduleJob(quartzJob, trigger);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            LOG.warn("Failed to schedule the job: {} with cron schedule: {}", job.getJobKey(), cronExpr);
        }
    }

    public void updateJobConfig(CartJobConfig jobConfig) {
        JobKey jobKey = jobConfig.getJobKey();
        boolean isEnabled = jobConfig.isEnabled();
        String cronStr = jobConfig.getCronSchedule();
        Map<String, String> jobDataMap = getJobDataMapFromJson(jobConfig.getJobContext());

        if (myDisabledJobs.contains(jobKey) && isEnabled) {
            myDisabledJobs.remove(jobKey);
            myJobCronSchedules.put(jobKey, cronStr);
            LOG.info("Enabling job: {}", jobKey);
            scheduleJob(jobKey, cronStr, jobDataMap);
            return;
        }

        if (!isEnabled && myDisabledJobs.add(jobKey)) {
            LOG.info("Disabling job: {}", jobKey);
            unscheduleJob(jobKey);
            return;
        }

        String oldCronStr = myJobCronSchedules.put(jobKey, cronStr);
        if (!cronStr.equals(oldCronStr)) {
            LOG.info("Cron schedule changed for job: {} to: {} from: {}", oldCronStr, jobKey, cronStr);
            scheduleJob(jobKey, cronStr, jobDataMap);
        }
    }

    public String getCronSchedule(CartJobKeyEnum jobkey) {
        return myJobCronSchedules.get(jobkey.getJobKey());

    }

    private Map<String, String> getJobDataMapFromJson(String jobContextJson) {
        Map<String, String> map = null;
        try {
            if (!StringUtils.hasText(jobContextJson)) {
                return null;
            }
            map = new ObjectMapper().readValue(jobContextJson, new TypeReference<Map<String, String>>() {
            });
        } catch (Exception ex) {
            LOG.error("Failed to parse json {}", jobContextJson, ex);
        }
        return map;
    }
}


public interface CartCronJob extends Job {
    public JobKey getJobKey();
}

I have added Lazy annotations and am confused how to use @PostConstruct or getter/setter injections. Here, myRegisteredJobs is a set of CartCronJob and RuntimePropertyLoader and CartJobConfigLoader both implement CartCronJob.

Circular dependency

I added all Lazy annotations in all combinations but nothing worked.

answers.body_markdown:
Karaf 4.4.x uses Pax Web 8 which includes complete refactoring of Whiteboard implementation (and entire structure).

One of the changes is related to specification compliance and servlets are _not_ initialized when registered - only lazily initialized on first request.

In servlet specification you can use `<load-on-startup>` in your `web.xml`, but OSGi CMPN Whiteboard specification doesn't mention this.

In Pax Web you can use `load-on-startup` service registration property though. So use:

    property = {
        HTTP_WHITEBOARD_SERVLET_PATTERN + "=/app/*",
        HTTP_WHITEBOARD_SERVLET_NAME + "=ApplicationConfiguration API",
        HTTP_WHITEBOARD_SERVLET_INIT_PARAM_PREFIX + ServletProperties.JAXRS_APPLICATION_CLASS
            + "=com.project.example.AppConfApplication",
        "load-on-startup=1"
    })

answers.body_markdown:
In order to obtain the depth data provided by the ARCore session, you need to write bytes into your local file. A Buffer object is a **container**, it countains a finite sequence of elements of a specific primitive type (here bytes for a ByteBuffer). So what you need to write inside your file is your `data` variable that corresponds to the information previously stored in the buffer (according to `buffer.get(data)`).

It works fine for me, I managed to draw the provided depth map within a python code (but the idea behind the following code can be easily adapted to a java code):

    depthData = np.fromfile('depthdata.txt', dtype = np.uint16) 
    H = 120 
    W = 160
    def extractDepth(x):
        depthConfidence = (x >> 13) & 0x7 
        if (depthConfidence > 6): return 0 
        return x & 0x1FFF 
    depthMap = np.array([extractDepth(x) for x in depthData]).reshape(H,W)
    depthMap = cv.rotate(depthMap, cv.ROTATE_90_CLOCKWISE)

For further details, read the information concerning the format of the depthmap (DEPTH16) here: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/ImageFormat#DEPTH16
You must also be aware that the depthmap resolution is set to `160x120` pixels and is oriented according to a landscape format. 

Make also sure to surround your code by a `try/catch` code bloc in case of a `IOException` error.

In order to obtain the depth data provided by the ARCore session, you need to write bytes into your local file. A Buffer object is a container, it countains a finite sequence of elements of a specific primitive type (here bytes for a ByteBuffer). So what you need to write inside your file is your data variable that corresponds to the information previously stored in the buffer (according to buffer.get(data)).

It works fine for me, I managed to draw the provided depth map within a python code (but the idea behind the following code can be easily adapted to a java code):

depthData = np.fromfile('depthdata.txt', dtype = np.uint16) 
H = 120 
W = 160
def extractDepth(x):
    depthConfidence = (x >> 13) & 0x7 
    if (depthConfidence > 6): return 0 
    return x & 0x1FFF 
depthMap = np.array([extractDepth(x) for x in depthData]).reshape(H,W)
depthMap = cv.rotate(depthMap, cv.ROTATE_90_CLOCKWISE)

For further details, read the information concerning the format of the depthmap (DEPTH16) here: https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/ImageFormat#DEPTH16 You must also be aware that the depthmap resolution is set to 160x120 pixels and is oriented according to a landscape format.

Make also sure to surround your code by a try/catch code bloc in case of a IOException error.

  public int getMillimetersDepth(Image depthImage, int x, int y) {
  // The depth image has a single plane, which stores depth for each

  Image.Plane plane = depthImage.getPlanes()[0];
  int byteIndex = x * plane.getPixelStride() + y * plane.getRowStride();
  ByteBuffer buffer = plane.getBuffer().order(ByteOrder.nativeOrder());
  short depthSample = buffer.getShort(byteIndex);
  return depthSample;
}

answers.body_markdown:
`ZoneOffset` *is a kind of* `ZoneId`! See the [declaration][1] in the documentation.

```
public final class ZoneOffset
extends ZoneId
```

There is no need for any extra steps. You can directly pass `ZoneOffset` objects to things that expects `ZoneId`s.

<hr>

If what you actually want to do is to find a *region-based* zone ID, e.g. `Europe/London`, from solely a `ZoneOffset`, there will likely be multiple such IDs that have the offset right now, or at any other particular instant.

To find the list of region-based IDs that is at a specified offset at a particular instant, you can do:

```
ZoneId.getAvailableZoneIds().stream()
    .map(ZoneId::of)
    .filter(id -> id.getRules().getOffset(theSpecifiedInstant).equals(theSpecifiedOffset))
    .collect(Collectors.toList());
    // or just .toList() in Java 16+
```


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/time/ZoneOffset.html
answers.title: Is there any way to convert ZoneOffset to ZoneId in Java 8?
answers.body:
ZoneOffset is a kind of ZoneId! See the declaration in the documentation.

public final class ZoneOffset
extends ZoneId

There is no need for any extra steps. You can directly pass ZoneOffset objects to things that expects ZoneIds.

If what you actually want to do is to find a region-based zone ID, e.g. Europe/London, from solely a ZoneOffset, there will likely be multiple such IDs that have the offset right now, or at any other particular instant.

To find the list of region-based IDs that is at a specified offset at a particular instant, you can do:

ZoneId.getAvailableZoneIds().stream()
    .map(ZoneId::of)
    .filter(id -> id.getRules().getOffset(theSpecifiedInstant).equals(theSpecifiedOffset))
    .collect(Collectors.toList());
    // or just .toList() in Java 16+

answers.body_markdown:
Use the available `ZoneRules` to find a suitable matching zone. There's **no** direct conversion  `ZoneOffset` represents a `fixed offset` from UTC, whereas a `ZoneId` represents a geographical region with *varying offsets due to daylight saving time changes*. Based on the above you can build one yourself to make that conversion. Here is a  [template][1]


  [1]: https://paste.c-net.org/ClawingDisorder
answers.title: Is there any way to convert ZoneOffset to ZoneId in Java 8?
answers.body: Use the available ZoneRules to find a suitable matching zone. There's no direct conversion ZoneOffset represents a fixed offset from UTC, whereas a ZoneId represents a geographical region with varying offsets due to daylight saving time changes. Based on the above you can build one yourself to make that conversion. Here is a template

answers.title: Is there any way to convert ZoneOffset to ZoneId in Java 8?
answers.body:
Java 11+: ZoneRules.getStandardOffset(Instant)

Gets the standard offset for the specified instant in this zone.

This provides access to historic information on how the standard offset has changed over time. The standard offset is the offset before any daylight saving time is applied. This is typically the offset applicable during winter.

That means if you have a ZoneId, you can get its rules by calling getRules() and get the standard offset of the Instant you provide to getStandardOffset(Instant). You could use Instant.now() as soon as you have the ZoneId from the front end.

example

public static void main(String[] args) {
    // example input
    ZoneId perth = ZoneId.of("Australia/Perth");
    // define an Instant
    Instant now = Instant.now();
    // determine the standard offset from the rules of the zone
    ZoneOffset perthStandardOffset = perth.getRules()
                                          .getStandardOffset(now);
    // and print it
    System.out.println(
            String.format("%s has a standard offset of %s at %s",
                          perth, perthStandardOffset,
                          now.atZone(ZoneOffset.UTC))
            );
}

output

Australia/Perth has a standard offset of +08:00 at 2023-06-07T07:41:38.082053Z
